Barrusk

From Peragro Tempus Wiki

The barrusk is a medium-sized, solitary carnivore which typically range in height (measured from the ground to the shoulder) between 85 and 90 centimeters (33 to 36 inches) in males, 5 to 10 centimeters (2 to 4 inches) less for females, and generally weigh between 46–70kg (101–154lbs). A few rare cases have been reported of barrusks weighing as much as 100kg (300 lbs).

Generally barrusks live on a diet of rodents and other small mammals, proving startlingly capable of burrowing or destroying other natural burrows with their claws and beak. Barrusks which have hunted out the rodent population of their territory, or sense an opportunity at a larger meal, will not hesitate to attack larger prey if they are reasonably confident of success- consequently, small children and the infirm are generally wary of reports of barrusks, and a mated pair can devastate stocks of deer and hunters alike.

The plumage which covers the barrusk's neck serves a dual purpose. The coloring, which shifts throughout the year, acts as camouflage, helping the barrusk hide while hunting, while the thickness and health of the plumage acts as a signal of quality for potential mates. A barrusk female has many periods of heat over the course of a year, each of which lasts about 4 to 7 days or until the female mates. Multiple males are attracted to a female in heat and will fight over her- the victor potentially winning the right to mate. At first, the female will reject the male, but eventually the female may allow the male to mate. The size of a barrusk litter averages two to eight young

Category: Creatures
